review.title: Color Aesthetics and Social Networks in Complete Tang Poems: Explorations and Discoveries
review.abstract: The Complete Tang Poems (CTP) is the most important source to study Tang poems. We look into CTP with computational tools from specific linguistic perspectives, including distributional semantics and collocational analysis. From such quantitative viewpoints, we compare the usage of "wind" and "moon" in the poems of Li Bai and Du Fu. Colors in poems function like sounds in movies, and play a crucial role in the imageries of poems. Thus, words for colors are studied, and "white" is the main focus because it is the most frequent color in CTP. We also explore some cases of using colored words in antithesis pairs that were central for fostering the imageries of the poems. CTP also contains useful historical information, and we extract person names in CTP to study the social networks of the Tang poets. Such information can then be integrated with the China Biographical Database of Harvard University.

sections.heading: 2 Data Sources and Basic Analysis
sections.text: Although we found several papers on the analysis of CTP, none of them specified exactly which version of CTP was used in their work. Although there is only one version of CTP in version 5 (qin1 ding4 si4 ku4 quan2 shu1), there are alternative versions of text.

sections.heading: 2.1 Data Sources
sections.text: There is no "the" authoritative version of CTP. However, in Taiwan's textbooks we find Li Bai's "the" (chuang2 qian2 kan4 yue4 guang1), but in Taiwan's textbooks we read "the" (chuang2 qian2 ming2 yue4 guang1), both of which are accepted by domain experts. We find online CTP in WikiSource7, Wenxue1008, Xysa9, Ctext10, ChillySpring11 and Guji12, for example. Most of these websites allow online reading, but do not allow full download, although some do. We have made a preliminary comparison between the versions of Wenxue100 and Ctext. They are very similar and seem to share a common source.In this paper, we are using the version we received from Wenxue100.

sections.heading: 3 Styles
sections.text: Using the concept of distributional semantics 19 (Harris, 1954; Miller and Walter 1991), researchers examine the semantics of a word from the distributions of its surrounding words. Firth (1957) stated, "You will know a word from the company that runs it." Similarly, we should be able to extend the concept of distributional semantics to comparing the styles of poets: "You will recognize a poet's style by the words he uses."

sections.heading: 4 Collocations and Antithesis
sections.text: Collocations refer to the occurrence of two words within a certain range. If two words appear constantly within a short range, they can have some close relationships in semantics. Antithesis refers to the parallelism in poems. Two words must have special relationships in their positions, pronunciations and meanings in order to form an antithesis pair. There are complex rules22 for observing antitheses and rhymes in Tang poems. In a Lu Shi poem, the third and fourth sentences form a sentence pair (, lian2), as well as the fifth and sixth sentences. A sentence pair should follow the anti-thesis rules. In a Lu Shi poem, the third and fourth sentences form a sentence pair (, lian2).

sections.heading: 6 Concluding Remarks
sections.text: Finding a needle in a haystack is a challenge for humans, but finding specific words in millions of words is easy for computers. With the applications mentioned above, we demonstrated the potential of computer tools to study the complete Tang poems, which are a bright spot in a fast-growing field of research - the Digital Humanities. Computer tools such as information gathering, text analysis and text mining cannot yet perform in-depth research, but they can help researchers find and collect much more relevant research material with amazing efficiency. It turns out that knowledge of the collection of words used by individual poets opens a window to observe the inner worlds of poets. The concept of distributional semantics has proven effective for the study of CTP. We still need to strengthen our ability to verify the limitations of pronunciation and rhymes in poems so that we can assess antitheses more precisely. The functions of colors in poems provide a stimulating direction for humans to actually use these zooming technologies in 2012.
